generif.text: GPR81 with relatively restricted expression in the adipose tissues functions as a receptor for lactate and can mediate an anti-lipolytic effect of lactate.

Data show that the coordinated PPARgamma-mediated regulation of the GPR81, GPR109A and GPR109B presents a novel mechanism by which TZDs may reduce circulating free fatty acid levels and perhaps ameliorate insulin resistance in obese patients.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Observational study of gene-disease association, gene-environment interaction, and pharmacogenomic / toxicogenomic. (HuGE Navigator)

demonstrated that the C165-E166-S167-F168 motif at the second extracellular loop is critical for GPR81 function, and the conserved six Cys residues at the extracellular regions are necessary for GPR81 function
Description of a GPR81 selective agonist with in vivo efficacy, inhibiting lipolysis without flushing.
Lactate negatively regulates TLR induction of the NLRP3 inflammasome and production of IL1beta, via ARRB2 and GPR81 in liver and pancreatic injury.
Data support that GPR81 is important for cancer cell regulation of lactate transport mechanisms.
HCA1/3 are necessary for breast cancer cells to balance lipid/fatty acid metabolism.
HCAR1 and monocarboxylate transporters activity is required for the L- and D-lactate-mediated enhancement of DNA repair and of HeLa cell survival.

Findings identify GPR81 as a tumor-promoting receptor in breast cancer progression and suggest a novel mechanism that regulates GPR81-dependent activation of the PI3K/Akt signaling axis in tumor microenvironment.
Lactate receptor/HCAR1 expression in cervical carcinoma cells may contribute to the modulation of cellular DNA repair mechanisms.

Activation of GPR81 decreases intracellular cAMP levels and inhibits PKA activity, leading to activation of TAZ and upregulation of PD-L1. This study reveals a critical role for lactate in the immune checkpoint pathway and an unexpected function of TAZ in tumor evasion of the T-cell-mediated immune response.
The novel role of HCAR1 in development of chemoresistance in cervical carcinoma HeLa cells via ABCB1 transporter up-regulation.
Monocarboxylate transporters in cancer.
Activation of GPR81 can rescue oscillatory shear stress -induced reduced expression of the key atheroprotective transcription factor KLF2.
The transcriptional response of GPR81 to lactate is mediated by Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3).
The lactate receptor GPR81 promotes breast cancer growth via a paracrine mechanism involving antigen-presenting cells in the tumor microenvironment.
Effects of GPR81 silencing combined with cisplatin stimulation on biological function in hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.
Heterogeneous ozone effects on the DNA methylome of bronchial cells observed in a crossover study.
HCAR1/MCT1 Regulates Tumor Ferroptosis through the Lactate-Mediated AMPK-SCD1 Activity and Its Therapeutic Implications.
Rare and potentially pathogenic variants in hydroxycarboxylic acid receptor genes identified in breast cancer cases.
Transcriptomic and functional studies reveal miR-431-5p as a tumour suppressor in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells.
Activation of lactate receptor HCAR1 down-modulates neuronal activity in rodent and human brain tissue.
The lactate sensor GPR81 regulates glycolysis and tumor growth of breast cancer.
Lactate receptor HCAR1 regulates cell growth, metastasis and maintenance of cancerspecific energy metabolism in breast cancer cells.
Insights into the regulation of podocyte and glomerular function by lactate and its metabolic sensor G-protein-coupled receptor 81.
The lactate receptor GPR81 is predominantly expressed in type II human skeletal muscle fibers: potential for lactate autocrine signaling.
History and Function of the Lactate Receptor GPR81/HCAR1 in the Brain: A Putative Therapeutic Target for the Treatment of Cerebral Ischemia.
Activation of GPR81 aggravated intestinal ischemia/reperfusion injury-induced acute lung injury via HMGB1-mediated neutrophil extracellular traps formation.
High Glucose Levels Promote Switch to Synthetic Vascular Smooth Muscle Cells via Lactate/GPR81.

BP.term: negative regulation of lipid catabolic process

name: hydroxycarboxylic acid receptor 1
summary: G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs, or GPRs), such as GPR81, contain 7 transmembrane domains and transduce extracellular signals through heterotrimeric G proteins.[supplied by OMIM, Feb 2005].
